markdownRemark.html:
This is an article I wrote for my company’s blog at Ekta.co documenting me and the runners-up contestants at the Company’s internal coding contest. It was the first time that I truly felt like a hackerman after winning the contest ;D.

Ekta Coding Challenge

At Ekta, we foster and encourage learning and creative problem solving. So we are kicking off with the first in a series of company wide coding challenges - and we’ll be showcasing our participant’s creative submissions!

The first challenge is specified below, with a two part submission - judged by our Senior Software Engineer Mark Franciose:

  1. The smallest/shortest solution, measured in characters (including white space).
  2. The most readable and well commented solution.

/* Challenge:

  • Create a function/functions that accepts an array of integers as a parameter
  • and filters out years which are not leap years.
  • A leap year is a year divisible by 4,
  • but years divisible by 100 are NOT leap years,
  • but years divisible by 400 ARE leap years
  • example: input [1, 1400, 1200, 2000, 2003, 2004] => output [1200, 2000, 2004]

*/

Submissions for shortest solution:

The submissions for the smallest/shortest solution comes from Mark Franciose and BinBin He.

Mark Franciose is a senior Software Engineer at Ekta with a background in web/android/ios application development.

“This solution abuses JavaScript’s automatic type coercion, order of operations and lack of need for whitespace. Never do anything like this except for funsies or to learn about the language. And even then, be kind to yourself and use white-space.” -Mark Franciose

His submission comes in at [41] characters:

l=y=>y.filter(x=>x%4<1&&x%100>0||x%400<1)

BinBin is a Software Engineer at Ekta with a background in firmware development for the Espressif, Arduino, & Raspberry Pi family.

“My solution uses the same tricks with javascript’s implementation of arrow functions, order of operations, and automatic type coercion as Mark. I manage to learn about bit-wise comparators to give me the lead in this competition! Fun fact, this solution beats some online javascript minifying programs!” -BinBin He

His submission comes in at [39] characters:

t=t=>t.filter(t=>t%4<1&t%100>0|t%400<1)

Submissions for most readable & well commented solution

The submissions for the most readable and well commented solution comes from Mark Franciose, BinBin He, and Harsh Gupta.

Mark’s submission:

“For readability and comprehensability I like to split any logical statement with more than 2 operations onto different lines. For this example, I think its more readable and easier to understand if the divisible by 400 case is separate. Additionally, the J-Doc style-comments can be parsed into pre-made documentation, and help whoever gets the code next to understand the intent of the person who wrote it” -Mark Franciose

/*

  • Filters an array of integers, returning those that are leap years
  • @param {number[]} years - valid integers, for calendar years
  • @return {number[]} leap years */

function leapYearsFilter(years) { return years.filter( year => { // case 1: year is divisible by 4 and not divisible by 100: if ( year % 4 == 0 && year % 100 != 0 ) return true; // case 2: year is divisible by 400: if ( year % 400 == 0 ) return true; // other cases: return false; })

}

BinBin’s submission:

“So the first thing you may notice is that… my submission doesn’t have any comments for the well written and well documented but I do have a good reason for that! I separated my solution into two digestible and logical units that serve only one purpose, i.e. the leapYearFilters() focuses on filtering out non-leap years from an array. The logic of identifying leap years is offloaded to leapYearCheck() which allows for easier modifications later on. I designate obvious and descriptive variable & function names - that made me think any comment I’d add would be redundant.” -BinBin He

function leapYearCheck(year){ if(year%4==0 && year%100!=0){ return true } else if(year%400==0){ return true } else{ return false } }

function leapYearFilter(yearsArray){ let leapYearsArray = yearsArray.filter(leapYearCheck) return leapYearsArray }

Harsh Gupta is a third year student at the University of Illinois at Chicago studying computer science and working as an intern at Ekta.

His submission:

“I started with writing down the conditions for leap year which is very specific. A leap year is a year divisible by 4, but years divisible by 100 are NOT leap years, but years divisible by 400 ARE leap years. I simply came up with an if-else block and made sure that every year which satisfies the condition is stored in an array. At the end, I return the array full of only leap years.” -Harsh Gupta

function leapYearFilter(years) { var leapYears = []; years.forEach( function(year) { if ((year % 4 === 0 && year % 100 !== 0) || (year % 100 === 0 && year % 400 === 0)) leapYears.push(year); }); return leapYears; }

frontmatter.title: Won company coding contest - Shortest Javascript leap year function!
Team won First Lego League award for Rising Star!
Won company coding contest - Shortest Javascript leap year function!
